United States Department of State / Foreign relations of the United States : diplomatic papers, 1945. General : the United Nations
			(1945)

 The United Nations conference on international organization, San Francisco, California, April 25-June 26, 1945, pp. 1-1432
			
 PDF (565.5 MB) 



Page 907


UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE
actually anxious to insure respect for the treaty of Russia with ApakL
MR. VANDENBERG replied that our respect for a treaty should connue
unless it were changed under the terms of they treaty.
 MR. PAsVOLSKY stated that the United States could not take an
independent position on this matter unless it first consulted with the
other members of the Big Five. After considerable debate,the Freich
had agreed to withdraw from their original position and had agreed
that the proposals should be incorporated in the Preable. MR.
RocR nmn i declared that the proposal had originatedrwith Chile
and Colombia,'8 but added that all the South American states seemed
to be in favor of it.
MIR. Nowre declared that the two-thirds.vote requirement was the
cause of our difficulty and that this would need adjustment soon. ML.
PAsVOLSKY agreed that the South American countries had adopted an
obstructionist position-but not on this issue. He declared that there
had been disagreement among the Latin American countries-on this
question in Washington before the Conference started.-
 MR. RocxuEFEu= asked where the Delegation- would stand- on a
matter which was related, namely, the introduction of wording in
Chapter V,rto bind the General Assembly to adhere to the principles
of the Organization established in Chapters I -and II.
 MN. PAsvOLSKY asked whether these amendments had been definitely
proposed as amendments, or whether they were merely in the specular
tive stage. If they had not been proposed definitely, he was of the
opinion that this should be done before consideration be givento them.
MI. ROCKEEL answered that there was no point in proposing
amendments if the United States Delegation was going to oppose
them. SECRETARY St'ErlNIus asked whether the Delegation would
be satisfied with incorporating this proposal in the Preamble, but
DEAN GnDERsuEVE remarked that she did not believe we could hold
that position. REPRESENTATVE BLoOM thought that the only place
for this proposal was in the Preamble. SENATOR VANDEMBERG re-
marked that he would favor the incorporation of the proposal in the
Principles, but would accept the Preamble. RPRESENTATI '-EATON
said that he favored the Preamble, while COMMANDER STASSEN said that
either was acceptable to him.
 MR. NoTrm expressed the view that the United States was being
victimized because of the two-thirds rule, but MR. RoacnJim said
that that was not the case because the United. States had not taken
a position. Once the position of the United States "I was established,
18Doc. 215, I/1/10, May 11, UNCIO Documents, vol. 6, pp. 528 and 536.
29 U.S. Gen. 216 and 217 on respect for treaties (letter from Mr. Armstrong
to
the Secretary, and memorandum from Mr. Dulles to the Secretary), neither
printed.
